text:
The heat load transferred to 101 ppmv (0.000157 Kg/m^3) of atmospheric CO2 (101 ppmv is the total increase in the mass of carbon dioxide since 1985), when the change of temperature on 2 August 2007 was only 1.23 K through one minute (ΔT/Δt)?:

q stored = m (Cp) (ΔT/Δt)

q stored = 0.000157 Kg (871 J/Kg * K) (1.23 K/60 s) = 0.0028 J/s

E = q (t) = 0.0028 J/s (1 s) = 0.0028 J = 0.00067 cal-th

To know the change of temperature caused by 0.00067 cal:

ΔT = Δq / m (Cp)ΔT = 0.00067 cal/0.000157 Kg (208.1 cal/Kg*K) = 0.00067 cal/0.0326717 cal*K = 0.02 K; or a change of temperature of 0.02 °C.

Since each kilogram of CO2 received 0.00067 cal, the temperature of each Kg of CO2, and therefore the entire volume of CO2, increased by only 0.02 °C.

Ref:  Nahle, Nasif. Heat Stored by Greenhouse Gases. Biology Cabinet. 27 April 2007. Obtained on  _06____(month)  _13____(day), _2016____(year); from http://biocab.org/Heat_Stored.html

text:
First, I believe that global warming is real.  You'd have to have your head in the sand to believe otherwise.  The "facts" support it. I've been trying to find articles or videos that support the case that man is causing global warming.  I wanted to find out more to arm myself in a debate.  Surprisingly, after watching hundreds of videos and reading several articles/papers, I've still found nothing that is convincing.  Most videos are like this one, which show the possible effects of long-term warming and make vague references to man being the cause.  But still, no hard statistics.  I'm a numbers guy and run in circles with other numbers people.  We are convinced by evidence and hard facts.  We consider videos like this more partisan propaganda vs education.  

Can anyone help me learn more?  This is what I've learned so far:

- There is a correlation between greenhouse gasses and the earths temperature.  Some scientists say greenhouse gasses cause a temperature rise and others say the temperature rise causes the gases.  I've not seen hard evidence either way...only circumstantial.

- After researching what "greenhouse gasses" are, it appears that about 3.7% is made up of CO2 and of that the rest (95%) is mainly water vapor.  Of the 3.7%, it looks like the manmade portion is around 11% of the 3.7%.  That translates into man made CO2 comprising less than 1/2 percent (0.4%) of total greenhouse gasses.  Of the 0.4%, scientist on both sides agree that it will take decades to reduce and at best we might get it down to 0.3% if the entire world participates. For those not good with numbers think about it this way. Take a pie and cut it into 100 pieces.  Then take one of those small pieces and cut it into 10 tiny pieces. Now pick up one of those tiny pieces...that is the amount we, as the world, might have control over.

- Of all the manmade CO2, China, India and Russia make up almost half of that.  At the last UN Global Warming Summit, these countries stated that they are not believers that man is causing the warming and have refused to participate in any global reduction agreements.   So, now cut that tiny piece of pie in half again.

- The US makes up about 16% of all manmade CO2 (. At the last UN Global Warming Summit, the US pledged it would reduce its manmade CO2 by 28% over the coming years. Some economist estimate this would cost close to $24 Trillion to accomplish or more than the total annual GDP of the US. 

Again, just trying to learn more of the facts.  If you have any, please share.  Thanks.

"The Earth is an evolving dynamic system. Current changes in climate, sea level and ice are within variability. Atmospheric CO2 is the lowest for 500 million years. How to explain Climate Change in simple terms that defeat denier's argument that since Carbon dioxide is necessary for Earth's systems to function normally, it is not a thing: 

Climate change is basically Earth's diabetes. 
While yes, Carbon dioxide (sugar) is necessary for its normal functions, too much of it (Carbon dioxide emissions) causes an imbalance that results in its systems to function improperly; resulting in the phenomenon known as Climate Change (diabetes).If nothing is done to fix this imbalance, then you run the risk of this condition (Climate Change/ diabetes) becoming permanent.

That is basically Climate change in a nutshell.

text:
1) Per IPCC AR5 Figure 6.1 prior to year 1750 CO2 represented about 1.26% of the total biospheric carbon balance (589/46,713). After mankind’s contributions, 67 % fossil fuel and cement – 33% land use changes, atmospheric CO2 increased to about 1.77% of the total biosphere carbon balance (829/46,713). This represents a shift of 0.51% from all the collected stores, ocean outgassing, carbonates, carbohydrates, etc. not just mankind, to the atmosphere. A 0.51% rearrangement of 46,713 Gt of stores and 100s of Gt annual fluxes doesn’t impress me as measurable let alone actionable, attributable, or significant.
2) Figure 10 in Trenberth et al 2011jcli24, in addition to substantial differences of opinion, i.e. uncertainties, 7 of the 8 balances considered, 87.5%, showed more energy leaving ToA than entering, i.e. atmospheric cooling.
3) Even IPCC AR5 expresses serious doubts about the value of their AOGCMs (IPCC AR5 Box TS.3 & TS.6).The sea ice and sheet ice is behaving as usual for decades (DMI) and does not affect sea levels. Polar bear population is the highest in decades, the weather (30 years = climate) is less extreme not more, the sea level rise is not accelerating, the GCM’s are repeat failures, the CAGW hypothesis is coming unraveled, COP21 turned into yet another empty and embarrassing fiasco, IPCC AR6 will mimic SNL’s Emily Letilla, “Well, neeeveeer mind!!”

Sun Spot Cycles are far more than 11 year cycles http://www.windows2universe.org/sun/activity/sunspot_history.html

Following Earth’s last ice age, which peaked 20,000 years ago, the 
Antarctic warmed between two and three times the average temperature 
increase worldwide.

"The Neglected Sun" attempts to explain why the IPCC's predictions of 
climate doom are so off the mark because the IPCC focuses solely on 
heating from human-related carbon dioxide. The authors state in 
relentlessly annotated, scientifically-supported arguments that natural 
climate variations play at least as large a role as carbon dioxide in 
modifying the Earth's climate. Cyclical variations in ocean temperature 
(critically the Pacific Decadal Oscillation), variations in the sun's 
magnetic field, and the sun's impact on cloud formation are shown to be 
critically important factors that are likely to impact our climate going
 forward. The authors even make the case for a slight cooling of the 
Earth in coming decades, offsetting the heating from anthropogenic 
carbon dioxide.


 via a number of indirect means (e.g., ice core samples) for estimating 
previous climatic conditions over many millennia that the earths has 
undergone significant changes in the past before man-made CO2 was a 
factor Of particular interest to today's discussion is the "Little Ice 
Age" 1400 to 1900 CE, and the "Medieval Warm Period" 1000 to 1400 CE. 
The latter experienced temperature conditions similar to our present 
"unprecedented" climate.

 Climate change is due to galactic cosmic rays emitted from distant 
exploding stars that trigger the formation of low clouds. Cosmic rays 
generate muons (elementary particles) that trigger the seeding of clouds
 by forming cloud condensation nuclei, on which water droplets form. 
Those low clouds have an umbrella cooling effect over our climate. The 
Sun has a fluctuating magnetic shield that partly protects against such 
rays. When the Sun is active and its magnetic shield is strong, the flow
 of cosmic rays is reduced, the low cloud cover diminishes and 
temperatures rise.

In addition to cosmic rays and their effect on Earth temperatures, there
 is a great deal of information on ice drilling and the wealth of 
ancient climate data stored in layers of ice in Greenland and the 
Antarctic. Much of that information contradicts what is often heard in 
the media and political speeches. Again, why hasn't this been in the 
mainstream news? My otherwise favorite radio network, NPR, speaks of 
"concensus" among "scientists" and labels anyone who doesn't buy climate
 change concensus as a flat-earther. Genuine scientists don't reach 
concensus on much of anything except maybe gravity, and this book is one
 more bit of evidence that there is no concensus among real scientists 
on global warming.


 The sun, including its magnetic cycles, and inner dynamics, exerts the 
major control on climate variability and climate change.

 Six different cycles of solar activity are documented. The climate 
history of the earth, including the last 150 years, correlate closely 
with these cycles which range from 11 to 2300 years. Moreover, some are 
amplified long term by Milankovich orbital parameters.

 The sun’s quantitative influence on climate change exceeds the 
influence of anthropogenic CO2, although the authors acknowledge that 
anthropogenic CO2 has a minor role to play in raising global 
temperatures. The supporting arguments are well-buttressed and 
convincing

The current temperature “Pause” is explained in terms of solar cycles 
and decreasing solar radiation. Likely, a period of cooling is ahead as 
solar radiation entering a diminished phase.

 (Has the IPCC really done its homework?), 6 (The misunderstood climate 
amplifiers), and 7 (A look into the future) provide the most detailed 
and accurate critique of the UN-IPCC’s reports. (I call it withering 
dissection). Thus, projected future temperature increases are expected 
to be much less than the UN-IPCC infers and the climate ‘crisis’ is 
overblown far too much. These chapters are incisive.

 EU UK and German climate and energy policy. They are instructive 
because the policies are failing, particularly as electricity costs have
 skyrocketed since implementation. This is becoming a universal problem.


“The New Little Ice Age Has Started.” This is the unambiguous title of a
 new study from one of the world’s most prestigious scientific 
institutions, the Russian Academy of Science’s Pulkovo Observatory in 
St. Petersburg. “The average temperature around the globe will fall by 
about 1.5 C when we enter the deep cooling phase of the Little Ice Age, 
expected in the year 2060,” the study states. “The cooling phase will 
last for about 45-65 years, for four to six 11-year cycles of the Sun, 
after which on the Earth, at the beginning of the 22nd century, will 
begin the new, next quasi-bicentennial cycle of warming.”  http://www.financialpost.com/m/wp/fp-comment/blog.html?b=business.financialpost.com/fp-comment/lawrence-solomon-proof-that-a-new-ice-age-has-already-started-is-stronger-than-ever-and-we-couldnt-be-less-prepared

natural phenomenon.

You can be on the right and believe that climate change is real and man made. text:
What a load of bull crap. 

The mean annual temperature of the Antarctica interior is −57 °C (−70.6 °F). The coast is warmer. Monthly means at McMurdo Station range from −26 °C (−14.8 °F) in August to −3 °C (26.6 °F) in January. Antarctica is going nowhere. 
Raise earths mean temperature 10 deg C and Antarctica would still not go anywhere, it would still contain the bulk of it's current ice volume. Possibly some of the outer rim floating ice could met, but none of that floating ice will cause a single millimeter in sea level change. (Anyone remember basic school physics?)

Typical of scaremongers this video tries to scare people by showing earths heat in terms of "Hiroshima nuclear bombs". Extreme scaremongering.

Get in your petrol fueled car and participate in giving us a greener and more food productive planet. At he Co2 levels we have today life is on the brink of starvation. If nature keeps depositing carbon in the earths crust then at some time in the future Co2 would reach below 150ppm. And life on earth would die.

Greenhouse growers put up to 1200ppm inh their greenhouse. Not for heat, but for growth. Plants are carbon based. Plants use the carbon in the atmosphere to build mass. We eat plants. Or animal that in turned ate plants. We are carbon based. Our bodies are built from Co2 that was in the atmosphere. Below 150ppm photosynthesis stops. And we all die. 
Give life on earth a better chance for long time survival by turning as much deposited carbon in the earths crust into Co2 as possible.
Planning to get a large muscle car from the -70s myself, because higher Co2 is good for us all. And contributes zero to any man made global warming. Changes in Co2 level follows temperature variations, not the other way around as is claimed by the intro text for this video.

Humanity is not the enemy of this planet, humanity is a part of this planet. A planet that can easily support 10 billion people if we stop stupidity.

The person who made this video is an idiot and doesn't understand the theory at all.
The warming does not come from the greenhouse effect of human emissions.  Only a small portion does in this theory, The majority of warming instead comes from a series of processes which are collectively called '"feedbacks"

This is why there is such a huge range in the predictions.  If it just worked on the greenhouse effect of c02 (which is very small)  then all the models would be the same.  You would not have the IPCC putting out an est8imate of between 2-6 degrees and having their margin of error double that of their low estimate

text: There are 3 sides to every argument.  Climate change is a process of evolution.  The Sun and its sun spots vary the Earth's temperature and Volcanos are the biggest threat and the shift of the continental plates resulting in planet shifts.  Over time the Earth will again balance the atmosphere.  Too much fresh water, such as excessive ice melting, can easily result in a new ice age similar to the one approximately 15,000 years ago. This is how the Great Lakes were formed by glaciers.   Too many clouds will cool the Earth.  It doesn't matter if the clouds are ash from volcanoes.   Too many climatologists, and not the quasi scientists, are providing inaccurate statistics refute the severity of climate changes.  Polar shift and magnetic changes are in all probability the next extinction cycle as there have been at least 5 in prehistoric times as geological experts have purported.  Humans need the cleanest environment for health but there are current scientific means of reducing carbon emissions without putting all people under inappropriate financial and social stress.

text: This is complete hysteria. Complete. Please, please, PLEASE just do a little research before churning out videos copied directly from media outputs. Look in to geology. Look into the history of the earth. Learn about the water cycle. Learn about the carbon cycle. Learn about BIOLOGY. PLEASE. Seriously, no one disputes that climate changes. It always has and always will, no matter what we do. But I beg you, learn a little about how life on earth works and how it has evolved before you brand carbon dioxide as some sort of 'zombie apocalypse' pollutant that we need to banish from the atmosphere for ever. Without CO2 in the atmosphere, zero life, yes ZERO, life exists in the form we currently entertain it. Having CO2 levels at 'target' 150ppm levels will essentially suffocate the photosynthesising plant life. And I don't need to tell you that if the plants die, we die. Not because we can't eat them, but because they produce the oxygen used in our own respiration. To say the CO2 levels currently are historically high is simply wrong. Even at current 400ppm levels, plants are on starvation rations. Look into geology and you'll realise hat levels of CO2 topping 2000ppm are not uncommon. Many many other, and more important, factors play a role in the climate of the planet apart from CO2. Water vapour and clouds will do multiples more to effect it than CO2 ever will. Please, don't just believe what you hear. Don't just believe me. Look into it. Do some study and draw your own conclusions. The climate may well be changing , but we're changing out of one of the coldest periods the earth has ever had, seriously. As Aden Bulgy correctly points out - we are currently in an Ice Age Ingerglacial. You want to stop the earth from warming up and doing what it it does. But have you ever asked the question; 'what would it be like if we do stop the warming and actually cool the planet down by 2 or 3 degrees?'. Probably not, because that would be getting closer to the 'zombie apocalypse' you talk of. Like it or lump it, life prefers warm to cold. Full stop.

text:
Here is the transcript, in case anybody wants to use this video in his lessons: 

This is a simple explanation of Climate Change based on an article in the New York Times. The average temperature on the surface of the planet has already increased 1.7 degrees Fahrenheit since 1880, which may not seem like much, but think about it this way: the heat from human emissions is roughly equal to 400,000 Hiroshima atomic bombs exploding across the planet every single day. Future generations are in big trouble. But for now it will gradually continue to get warmer and storms will grow more intense, with longer periods of drought in between. But longer-term, if emissions continue to rise unchecked, the climate disasters will be so severe they will destabilize entire nations, send millions of refugees across borders, cause widespread extinction of most species on Earth and melt the polar ice caps, leaving most of the world’s coastal cities several feet underwater. All this could take centuries, but something like the sudden collapse of agriculture would trigger immediate chaos in society.

Best case is we get our act together and begin to rapidly bring emission levels down. Meanwhile, Earth turns out to be less sensitive to greenhouse gases than we currently believe, plants and animals adapt quickly and major technological breakthroughs help society limit emissions and adjust to Climate Change. But, these are all the opposite of what we are actually seeing, so the only thing in our control is to limit emissions using all available tools and best behaviors currently at our disposal. 

Worst case, the collapse of food production causes spiraling prices and – as our capitalist utopia breaks down – billions starve as our world gets violent and messy real quick – kind of like a zombie apocalypse, but with extreme hunger spreading chaos instead. This would be coupled with the melting of the Antarctic ice-sheet, leading to rapidly rising seas, that would force us to abandon many of our greatest cities and all of the social and scientific progress that we were making within them. Adding insult to injury is the fact that many of the emissions were emitted while building these now abandoned, underwater metropolises. 

If emissions continue unchecked, we are looking at a total rise of between 80 to 160 feet, which would occur if all the ice in the poles melted. So the oceans will rise, the real question is how fast? Scientists only have Earth’s history to base their predictions on, which suggests that the rate has occasionally hit 1 foot per decade. So we will have to adapt to an altered coastline sooner or later, but probably much sooner than later. Because computer forecasts only give us a range of future possibilities, the most important evidence comes from the studies of past climate conditions, which clearly show that every time the amount of carbon dioxide in the air rises, the Earth warms up, ice melts and the ocean rises. What’s important to remember here is that we are in uncharted territory – humans are pumping carbon dioxide into the air far faster than nature ever has before us. 

Scientists have been publishing strong evidence that warming is making drought and heat waves more frequent, causing heavier rainstorms and more severe coastal flooding. But while the Internet has made us all more aware if weather disasters in distant countries, it is hard to prove these are all directly made worse by Climate Change. 

Canada and Russia both have vast, frozen lands and could see some economic benefits from a warmer climate. Putin and the Russians and until recently Canada as well, have been reluctant to make ambitious climate commitments. But expect that to change as these countries realize they will be swamped by millions of refugees from less fortunate nations. Libertarians and other political conservatives do not like the policies proposed to fight Climate Change and have chosen to try and block them by actively undermining the science. This effort has been funded by the oil and coal industry, who favor making money above all else. As more resources are devoted to solving the problem, our chances at big technological breakthroughs are improving, but we still should be spending about three times as much money as we currently are on these efforts according to several in-depth reports. 

You can reduce your carbon footprint by doing things like plugging leaks in your home insulation, installing a smart thermostat, taking public transit, taking less airplane trips, buying an electric car and putting solar panels on your roof. A big one is eating less meat. But what’s really needed is for you to speak up and exercise your rights as a citizen, because strong, collective action through state and national policies is how we will make the most impact. 

Considering that we have been ignoring scientists’ warnings since the 80’s to limit emissions, we are pretty late in the game. But we have finally reached a moment where nearly every country in the world agrees this is a huge problem and seem to commit to taking at least some kind of action. Leading corporations will continue to make bold promises to do their part, low-emission technologies will improve and many states and cities will go much further than any goal set by their national governments. The United States, the world’s biggest economy, is finally starting to move aggressively and China, the world’s largest emitter, is beginning to recognize that it needs to do the same, as many of its megacities will be underwater if the seas rise too high. But it is up to us, the ordinary citizens, to continue demanding our political leaders tackle Climate Change, the hardest problem that humanity has ever faced.

text:
This is absolute nonsense.  The most recent global temperature measurements show NO CHANGE in the average global temperature.  The level of atmospheric CO2 has risen from 300 ppm to 400 ppm since the beginning of the industrial age, but there is no proof human activity is the primary, or even a significant cause. The CO2 level has been much higher at several times in the distant past, sometimes much higher than 1,000 ppm, and no runaway in global temperatures resulted.

That is why this video has the words "Climate Change" in its title instead of the more familiar "Global Warming". The Climate change mountebanks are preparing for the day when they can abandon global warming in favor of some other trendy cause celebre.

Perhaps the next one will have some actual truth behind it......

text:
@lucky time   Opinions are like buttholes....everyone has one and THEY ALL STINK.
Google the Milankovitch Cycles...we have clear records....and human activities have interrupted these cycles, Earth's most powerful natural Cycles.
"  CO2 works with & led the natural cycles  " ? 
"... Natural global warming, and cooling, is initiated by Milankovitch cycles. These orbital and axial variations influence the initiation of climate change in long-term natural cycles of 'ice ages' and 'warm periods'  known as 'glacial' and 'interglacial' periods. Our current climate forcing shows we are outside of that natural cycle forcing range.
\
Milankovitch Cycles
Where are we currently in the natural Milankovitch cycle?
Pre-industrial forcing estimated around 0.0 to -0.1W/m2
.
The natural cycle that people refer to regarding large scale climate change 
is the time between ice ages and warm periods. The long cycle time is about 100,000 years. 
.
We can spend around 20% of the cycle in an interglacial and around 80% in an ice age, depending on where we are in these cycle influences.
.
What causes this is the natural cycles that influence earth climate – the Milankovitch Cycles?
The Milankovich cycles are caused by changes in the shape of the Earth's orbit around the sun, 
the tilt of the Earth's rotation axis, and the wobble of our axis. 
The mass and movement of the other planets in our solar system actually affect the Earth orbit 
just as our planetary mass similarly affects their orbits.
As the Earth's orbit changes so too do the amount of sunlight that falls on different latitudes and in seasons. 
The amount of sunlight received in the summer at high northern latitudes appears to be especially important to determine whether the Earth is in an ice age or not. 
When the northern summer sun is strong, the Earth tends to be in a warm period. 
When it is weak we tend to be in an ice age.
As we come out of an ice age, 
the sea level rises about 400 feet, and we enjoy a warm period 'like' the one we are in now. That is the natural cycle, brief warm periods followed by an ice age about every 100 thousand years.
There are three general factors that determine the forcing changes in the Milankovitch cycles.
Eccentricity 
(the elliptical changes in the earth's orbit around the sun)
Obliquity (the tilt of Earth's axis toward and away from the sun)
Precession (the wobble of Earth's axis toward and away from the sun)
.
The two terms you want to be familiar with in the Milankovitch cycles are perihelion and aphelion.
These terms pertain to proximity to, and/or climate forcing from solar energy.
Perihelion 
is when Earth spends more time in close proximity to the sun, or in the case of the tilt and wobble cycles 
when the northern hemisphere landmass facing the sun is closest to the sun, causing warming.
Aphelion 
is the opposite, when the Earth spends more time during the year away from the sun, 
or in the case of the tilt and wobble cycles when the northern hemisphere landmass facing the sun is 
further from the sun, causing cooling.
The Eccentricity Cycle (Elliptical Cycle)
.
This is the longer cycle. 
About every 100k years. 
When the Earth orbit is elliptical we spend less time 
close to the sun in the span of a single year. 
This means we get less solar energy on an annual basis and tend to cool the Earth.
.
According to Ralph Keeling, Director of the CO2 program at Scripps Institute of Oceanography:
“The ice sheets melt when the ice sheet is exposed to more summer sunlight. 
This happens when the northern summer aligns with the point of the closest approach between the earth and the sun. 
The point of closest approach is known as perihelion. The earth/sun perihelion depends on how elliptical the orbit is. 
The more elliptical, the closer the approach.”
.
The Obliquity Cycle (Axial Tilt)
The Axial Tilt, or obliquity, varies to the plane of the Earth's orbit. 
This tilt, 
typically around 23 1/2 degrees can vary between 22 and 24 1/2 degrees. 
That means it can change up to 2.5 degrees over a period of 41,000 years. 
Increased obliquity can cause summers to be warmer and winters to be colder.
So when our orbit is elliptical and our northern hemisphere, 
which is mostly landmass is tilted toward the sun, we can melt our way out of an ice age
 pretty fast in fact it only takes a few thousand years.
As we attain a more circular orbit and the combined effects of the tilt and 
wobble work together in their natural cycles the Earth has a chance to cool again and we go back into an ice age.
.
Inversely, 
decreased obliquity can cause cooler summers that in combination with other factors can help push the climate system into ice ages when this cycle is favorable for that condition.
******* We are currently in a decreasing phase, 
which under normal circumstances, 
without the excess GHG’s, would cool the climate system.
.
The Precession Cycle (Wobble)
Next is precession, or wobble.
This cycle occurs every 26,000 years. This gyroscopic wobble of the earth's axis is driven by tidal forces which are influenced by our sun and moon. The Earth is actually not perfectly round so the gravitational pull tugs the axis over time creating the wobble cycle. 
.
Now there's a technical term for you.
This wobble can cause a difference in the types of seasons one polar hemisphere will experience over the other. 
The hemisphere at perihelion (closest to the sun) will enjoy an increase in summer solar radiation but a cooler winter, 
while the opposite hemisphere will have a warmer winter and a cooler summer.
Currently, 
the southern hemisphere is at perihelion, so they are enjoying warmer summers, 
but cooler winters, which likely contributes to snowfall in the hemisphere.
.
Natural Cycle Departure
The natural cycle is range bound and well understood, 
largely constrained by the Milankovitch cycles. Since the beginning of the industrial age, 
humankind has caused such a dramatic departure from the natural cycle, 
that it is hard to imagine anyone thinking that we are still in the natural cycle.
.
Natural vs. Modern Forcing
Climate Forcing & Temperature
Natural vs. Modern Climate Path
Mheel Attribution Chart
.
This departure is so dramatic that it has instigated a new era.
.
According to research studies, 
there is enough evidence to state that we have departed the Holocene 
and 
entered the Anthropocene.
*
***** Simply put, 
based on the evidence, mankind has forced the Earth climate system to depart from it's the MOST POWERFUL natural cycle 
GLACIATION!
.

text: +Martin Poulter Ya, I know it sounds a bit confusing but there is no contradiction here. My statement on CO2 levels is not in conflict with that article. As one of them said in the article "CO2 concentrations have not been this high for millions of years. - Dr. Erika Podest" What she did not tell you is that it has been falling as a clear trend for 600 million years. Before the rise began circa 1900s, CO2 was at (250 ppm). Considering CO2 levels have been as high as 7000 ppm (2700 ppm average), 400 ppm today is not that bad (400 ppm levels existed about 20 million years ago). Read the article and their wording and it says "has never risen this fast before". It is the speed of rise they are worried about. Also remember that we are in an ice age (all glaciers, Arctic and Antarctic as well as Greenland are ice free in the summer when we are not in an active ice age).
author: Scott Mana

text: @Scott Mana  So human civilization has built up during an ice age. Many cities, each housing millions of people, have been built in areas that are only dry land because it's an ice age. If we melt the ice those cities will be unlivable, the glaciers that provide millions of people with fresh water will be gone. How is this a good thing? How is getting the world back to what it was like before human civilization a good thing?
author: Martin Poulter

text: +Martin Poulter Looking at just the last 18,000 years, sea level rise has always been present. An Estimated 90% of our cities are under water. Oddly, our historic accounts give very little mention of it. I think because it is so slow. Interrupting the last 2.6 million years of ice age are warm spells that are short lived (every 100,000 years or so the spells last about 10,000 years). We are in one such spell right now.We have always been subject to climate change, just as we are right now. We fixate on the bad because it hurts, yet there are good things too. Northern latitudes up to the arctic circle become tropical, opening up fantastic amounts land for people to live on that outweighs land loss. Fresh water from rain becomes more common and better yet, the climate becomes much more stable. Almost everything flourishes in warm weather, even us. However, before we consider this too much, there is another alternative. While cast off by climate science it has not been ruled out by any means, our warm spell is scheduled to end soon (no one knows when), if scientist have concluded the wrong driver of climate, we will not see this warmer future, rather the warm spell will end and we will go back to a full ice age. Either way, change will spell disaster for people who will be forced to do as they have always done, adapt.

+Daniel May We'd love to, but in reality, the only reason why nuclear power was ever adopted was because of resources for nuclear bombs. Basically, the left wanted it because of fuel security, scientific value and emissions, and the case couldn't be funded unless the authoritarians met them half way for their ambition of nuclear warfare. Mind you, nuclear power was in its stride during the cold war.


Again, nuclear power is awesome, but it can and has been used recklessly. Given how expensive (and bottomless) nuclear power is right now, a new plant could never be funded by the public through environmental reasons at most. It would be distasteful to approve of something knowing that it would be used for weaponry and war preparation. 


Another reason why we are just skeptical of nuclear power is geographical location and planning. Too close to high energy shore lines, tectonic activity, depleted waste disposal and out dated methods of electricity production are all factors we see as too high to risk to public and wildlife health.


Even simple planning issues that concern most regular powerplants such as wind flow and accumulation. That's important given where the emissions are blown away to, like in a basin to the nearest town or city. The same goes for waste disposal by river or sea. Sellafield is a prime example in the Irish sea.

author: Edmonton Rails

text:
The climate is continuously changing. Everyone believes in 'climate change'. Only the naive use this term. 
'Anthropogenic global warming', is the correct term and AGW is a myth created by globalists. The alarmists use 'climate change' instead of AGW because they know that AGW is not significant.
Humans have put back into the atmosphere a small fraction of the CO2 that nature has taken out. Plants are prospering because of this. 
The people I listen too are the experienced climate scientists who have spent most of their lives on studying and researching climate. Scientists who are honest enough to give us their truthful opinion and who have an in-depth understanding of the Earth's climate.
Some of these scientists might gain from Oil Companies who want to reward them for reducing the hysteria, but most of these scientists are retired, have no further interest in gaining money and have not accepted money. They are genuine in their expressed beliefs and want to expose the lies.
There are many videos of older highly acclaimed scientists exposing the alarmists. Eg Prof Ivar Giaever, Dr Don Easterbrook,  Murry Salby, Prof Ian Plimer, Prof Bob Carter, Prof Fred Singer, Prof Freeman Dyson, Prof Patrick Michaels, Prof Garth Paltridge, Dr Richard Siegmund Lindzen etc. 
Older scientists can more easily speak their mind because they have nothing to lose w.r.t. career prospects.

For the politically aware, view the channel RockingMrE . One of his videos is titled, The Globalist Agenda Explained

text: +SPACEMONKEY288 But Sanders opposeses the TPP, something this channel remained unbiased about by talking about the pros and the cons. Sanders just uses Wall Street (The stock exchange?) as a scapegoat blaming them for most everything wrong with the world today.
author: Ryan McCarthy

text: @Ryan McCarthy  TPP is a bad deal.
author: SPACEMONKEY288

text: Don't say that if you can't provide reasons and evidence to support your claim. You'll have to clarify for someone to even humor your statement. So please, enlighten me.
author: Ryan McCarthy

text:
+Ryan McCarthy 
Reasons? Well, first it will allow corporations to sue governments trying to limit their emissions. It will also outsource jobs which as America already struggles to put its citizens to work is an issue, and finally it will involve monopolising companies and massive banks and will likely push back all work on climate change. Tell me, what positives outweigh this?
author: CMDR Dantae

text:
It would allow corporations to sue governments for infringing on the trade deal as well. It also brings labour conditions in countries up to a set standard (so, if China were to join, they wouldn't have such inhumane working conditions). As for monopolization, you'd have to be much more specific on what you mean, because in my debates about Sanders, most people don't.

As for a positive outweigh, that doesn't hinge on any of what I just covered? Well, America is not an industrial country anymore, and honestly it should remain that way. As the economy shifts more towards service based industries (a cause of being a post-industrial nation) we tend not to manufacture nearly as many items as we have in the past. It seems to me like the only people who'd lose on that deal are Sander's main source of income (money in washington and special interests), unions.
author: Ryan McCarthy

text:
@Ryan McCarthy 
You do realise that could make corporations more powerful that governments. Especially since it could affect fight against climate change.

What exact benefits do the deal have, all of the people that put it forward are lobbyists and it would lose 1 million jobs. There is already an employment issue. This would privatise free health and education, and could have serious effects.

Oil industries could sue for pushes to sustainable energy.
author: CMDR Dantae

text:
Nafta lost jobs when it was first implemented, but began to show its benefits as time progressed, so I don't fear job losses. At the most, we'd lose a few manufacturing jobs, but that's bound to happen eventually, and this way, developing countries will be able to develop.

There are already privatized health here in the US, as well as private schools, but we still have a large amount of people going to public institutions,  and so it definitely wouldn't cease to exist.

Pushes into sustainable energy aren't going to be feasible for a while yet, at least on a massive scale. I mean, there's actually a tax being implemented in oregon (i believe) that is taxing how far people drive. It's being implemented because more people have hybrid/electric vehicles and use less gasoline, which the government is now losing tax revenue on.

This would allow an oil industry to sue if the government put tariffs on oil (breaching the trade agreement) so people would be more likely to switch to sustainable energy. Not just because they're incentivising it, unless it's in the form of subsidies, which is giving preferential treatment to businesses anyway.
author: Ryan McCarthy

text:
@Ryan McCarthy 
Oil gets just as many subsidies. They usually don't pay the back either. Tesla paid back all of its subsidies of $1.5 billion the following year. Why would people be more likely to switch to sustainable energy if there are no tariffs on oil? There are already states that are trying to ban electric cars like the Tesla.
author: CMDR Dantae

text:
That's because the economy of the state is dependent on the auto industry, such as Michigan. What about people banning uber because the taxi industry can't compete with it? 

Don't get me wrong, I support sustainable energy over oil, but that doesn't mean we through entire industries (not only jobs, but some states like Alaska are dependent on oil for income) under the bus. As for tariffs, you'd still be violating a free trade agreement, and if a company doesn't sue (it wouldn't be wrong of them if they did) other nations in the agreement would definitely have an issue with you.
author: Ryan McCarthy

text: +Ryan McCarthy sanders isn't using wall street as a scapegoat. wall street has screwed the American people. they own are politicians. the banks are too big. most of them should be in jail.they break the economy then bailed out just to return the same bubble that caused the recession in the first.
author: JurassicDalek

text:
While I agree that banks are simply too big, the centralized banks in the U.S (such as the federal reserve) are no better either. Even with banks being too big, that's no excuse to call out other industries or investors. The recent recession was caused by too much lending as well, not because Wall Street made it so, and that means all parties are involved, including the government. 

We can see how well the government handles its own ventures too. Just take a look at Amtrak or the current water crisis in Flint. It's private transportation services doing well, and private corporations donating water to the citizens in Flint.
author: Ryan McCarthy

text:
@Ryan McCarthy 
Doesn't count. Flint is corruption. Apparently emails were leaked showing a safer deal that was 800 million dollars cheaper, so they paid more for toxic water, essentially. I would blame the government if they were one.
author: CMDR Dantae

text:
Although, they're also blamed for things that aren't their fault. I remember the Koch brothers often get this end of the stick. 

For example, they're hated for supporting the Keystone pipeline. On the other hand, Warren Buffet is praised for standing against it. What people don't realize is that oil that doesn't travel through pipelines have to travel on trains, a much more risky means of transporting oil. Buffet has stock in the rail industry, so of course he'd be against the pipelines. Yet, Koch is still hated for their support.

For another example, you've got people saying how much better electric cars are. However, lithium (for the batteries) mines are absolutely awful for the environment and physical ecosystem in an area (open pit mines), compared to more compact means of oil extraction.

On the flip side, for some reason they take the blame for the rainforests being cut down. However, that's not really on them. In places like Brazil, their being cut down to make room for farmland so people in Brazil will have a stable supply of food. 

Global warming, pollution, and the environment are really difficult issues when put into a ring with businesses and industry, often becoming a "damned if you do, damned if you don't" argument.
author: Ryan McCarthy

text:
@Ryan McCarthy 
From what I've heard the pipeline would have destroyed a lot of nature reserves, which would have offset the reduced emissions.
author: CMDR Dantae

text: But, the pipeline is far safer than any other method of transportation. I'm not very sure how it would have destroyed nature reserves. Impacted portions of them maybe, but destroy seems like a bit of a stretch.
